abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment reviews
            the environmental framework and legislation in Mozambique,
            and in particular, the impacts of mining activities on the
            environment, and the analytical capabilities to be
            correspondingly wide-encompassing. Mining may cause
            pollution to water, to air and the contamination of soils
            and sediment, hence laboratories need to be able to analyze
            solid, liquid, and gaseous samples. It is foreseen that the
            Department of Environment shall require analytical services,
            both for the control of discharges from mines, and for the
            determination of background conditions in various natural
            environments. The analysis for mercury related to
            contamination from artisanal mining is a possible future
            need, if Mozambican authorities decide to embark on an
            investigation of this potentially serious problem. This
            would mean the analysis for mercury in such media as natural
            soils; stream sediments; water (less likely as the
            solubility of mercury in water is extremely low); fish (or
            other fauna); and, human hair and blood. Such analyses
            requires sophisticated equipment to determine expected low
            concentrations, as well as strict routines for cleanliness,
            and inter-laboratory quality control. The inefficient use of
            natural resources creates the following potential problems:
            incomplete recovery of ore reserves in mine or deposit; poor
            recovery of metals/minerals in the beneficiation process;
            and, wastefulness regarding consumption of water and energy.
            Sources or reasons for this are the use of unsuitable mining
            methods, inferior beneficial methods, and/or poor
            optimization of processes, slack management and work
            routines. Recommendations include implementation of baseline
            studies in regions where future mining is expected to take
            place, or in areas of ecological sensitivity. It is
            suggested to study groundwater conditions, as well as the
            vegetation characteristics of coastal areas hosting deposits
            of titanium-rich heavy mineral sands. In addition,
            guidelines for occupational health and safety matters at
            mining sites should be developed, in close cooperation with
            the Department of Mine Safety.
